 I believe 9-11 would have happened even if Gore had been elected. We are infinitely better off than we would have been under his "leadership". You shouldn't blame all the ails of the economy on Bush just as you shouldn't blame 9-11 on Bush...unless of course, you think Bush caused the dot.com collapses and Enron type business failures.

 Grow up!

 
 Grow up ??? I thought the purpose of this forum was to debate issues without attacking each other. We'll never know what would have happened if Al Gore was elected so I refuse to speculate on that issue. Bush is under the magnifying glass because he is president and his actions affect all of us, therefore what he does is fair game for discussion. You have to realize that a large number of Americans weren't and aren't for the Iraq war. Everyday there is a constant reminder in the news to fuel that fire. If you want to post propaganda about the war, you have to be ready to defend it. If you personally feel safer as a result of the invasion, your choice in November will be clear, for everyone else that never thought Iraq or Saddam was a threat to us, we'll take a look at all the candidates. I never blamed George Jr. for the recession, I only judge him on what he's done to get us out of it.

 No, that number, somewhere around 350,000 claimaints in a specific initial claim group, is slated for reduction through 06/04 as their benefits are exhausted and federal extensions have been suspended. That means you'll be reading more and more 'good news' of 'unemployment claims drop'. 
 
 But maybe there's hope for them with plenty of talk going around about reviving the draft. If draftees get the same pay/benefits as regular troops now receive, most could be making more than at their former occupations. Some risks, but a government funded college education and 'readjustment allowance' is part of the deal. Let's see, it took Saddam 400,000 troops to control Iraq, so the numbers would be about right.
